title-group.article-title: In vitro cytotoxicity and structure-activity relationship approaches of entkaurenoic acid derivatives against human breast carcinoma cell line

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: In vitro cytotoxicity and structure-activity relationship approaches of entkaurenoic acid derivatives against human breast carcinoma cell line

Ricardo M. da Costa a,b
, Jairo K . Bastos
c
, Maria C .A. Costa
d
, Márcia M. C . Ferreira
d ,
Cássia S. Mizuno e , Giovanni F. Caramori f , Gláucio R. Nagurniak f , Marília R. Simão a ,

Núcleo de Pesquisa em Ciências Exatas e Tecnológicas da Universidade de Franca - UNIFRAN, Franca , SP, Brazil

Faculdade de Ciências Farmacêuticas de Ribeirão Preto , Universidade de São Paulo , Ribeirão Preto , SP, Brazil

A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Copaifera
ssp (Fabaceae-caesalpinoiodidaeae) Multivariate QSAR analysis
Kaurenoic acid derivatives
MCF-7 breast cancer cells
PLS regression
A B S T R A C T

In this study, ent -kaurenoic acid derivatives were obtained by microbial transformation methodologies and tested against breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7). A multivariate quantitative-structure activity relationship (QSAR) analysis was performed taking into account both microbial transformation derivatives and other analogues previously reported in literature to give some insight into the main features behind the cytotoxic activity displayed by kaurane-type diterpenes against MCF-7 cells. The partial least square regression (PLS) method was employed in the training set and the best PLS model was built with a factor describing 69.92% of variance and three descriptors (log P , εHOMO and εHOMO–1 ) selected by the Ordered Predictors Selection (OPS) algorithm. The QSAR model provided reasonable regression ( Q 2 = 0.64, R 2 = 0.72, SEC = 0.29 and SEV = 0.33). The model was validated by leave- N -out cross-validation, y-randomization and external validation ( R 2 pred = 0.89 and SEP = 0.27). The selected descriptors indicated that the activity was mainly related to electronic parameters (HOMO and HOMO- 1 molecular orbital energies), as well as to log P . These findings suggest that higher activity values are directly related with both higher log P and frontier orbital energy values. The positive relationship between these orbitals and the activity suggests that the ent -kaurenoic acid analogues interaction with the target involves charge displacement, which is entirely consistent with the literature. Based on these findings, three compounds were proposed and one of them was synthesized and tested. The experimental result confirmed the activity predicted by the model.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: 1 -R1 = COOH; R2 = H ; R3 = H ; R4 = H
2 -R1 = COOH; R2 = OH; R3 = H ; R4 = H
3 -R1 = COOH; R2 = H ; R3 = H ; R4 = OH

6 -R1 = COOCH 3 ; R2 = OH; R3 = H ; R4 = H
7 -R1 = COOH; R2 = H ; R3 = H ; R4 =
O
8 -R1 = CH 2 OH; R2 = H ; R3 = H ; R4 = H
9 -R1 = COOCH 3 ; R2 = H ; R3 = H ; R4 = H

OH R R H H 11 -R = N 19 -R = N OC H 3 12 -R = N 20 -R = H 21 -R = NH 13 -R = N H 22 -R = N H 14 -R = N H 23 -R = N H OCH 15 -R = N 3 OCH 3 H 24 -R = N H 16 -R = N H 25 -R = N H OH 17 -R = N OH H 26 -R = N 18 -R = H 27 -R = N N

In 2010, Hueso-Falcon and coworkers (
) synthesized a series containing thirty-one ent -kaurane derivatives, from which four were considered as potent apoptosis inducers in human tumor cells through a caspase-dependent mode of action. In another study, by Batista and coworkers (Batista et al., 2013), the in vitro citotoxicity of oxidized/epoxidized kaurenoic acid analogues was assessed against ovary, breast, melanoma, lung, leukaemia, pancreas, colon and cervical cancer cells. From their results, two allylic alcohol derivatives showed to be the most potent ones, displaying very promising GI 50 values, ranging from 0.71 to 8.90 μM (Batista et al., 2013). More recently, Simão and coworkers (Simao et al., 2016) investigated the ability of a series of amides and diols derivatives of compound 1 to inhibit the growth of a human breast carcinoma cell line. Among the obtained analogues, one diterpene exhibited significant activity, displaying an IC 50 value of 7.84 μM and a selectivity index of about 50.7. It was also observed in this study that the presence of an amide containing an aromatic moiety in kaurenoic acid, instead of the carboxylic acid group, significantly increased the activity and the selectivity of the obtained derivative (Simao et al., 2016). Such findings brought an insight to investigate the structure–activity relationship displayed by kaurenoic acid structural analogues against tumor cell lines.

In the present study, kaurenoic acid derivatives were obtained through fungal transformation using
Aspergillus terreus
strains. Moreover, other kaurane-type diterpenes previously reported (
; Simao et al., 2016) were also employed to perform a multivariate data analysis (partial least squares regression - PLS), including QSAR studies against a human breast carcinoma cell line. Based upon the information obtained from QSAR analysis, three kaurenoic acid derivatives were proposed - one of them was synthesized and also evaluated against MCF-7 cell lines (compound 27 ).

sec.title: 2.1. Microbial transformation of kaurenoic acid (compound 1)
sec.p:
Fourteen-days incubation of compound 1 , isolated from
Copaifera
ssp, with
Aspergillus terreus
strains gave rise to four derivatives ( 2, 3, 4 and 5 ), which were isolated with a yield ranging from 2.2 to 24.3% based on their weights relative to the starting substrate. Due to the high rate converting of diterpene 2 from 1 , this metabolite was used as substrate to obtain its respective methyl ester ( 6 ), which was also evaluated against MCF-7 cells. The spectral data of all compounds are in agreement with that previously reported in the literature, 2 (Silva et al., 1999); 3 (Vichnewski et al., 1977); 4 (
); 5 (
). The chemical structures of substrate ( 1 ) as well as of the derivatives obtained by microbial transformation are presented in Fig. 1 .

In this work, we found that
A. terreus
catalyzed stereoselective hydroxylation of non-activated carbons of 1 , mainly at C-7, C-11 and C-15 ( Fig. 1 ). This strain also promoted the introduction of a hydroxyl moiety at C-16 (double bond), denoting its great versatility to obtain novel derivatives from kaurane-type diterpenes. The reactions performed by this fungus are particularly interesting as this kind of transformation is very difficult to achieve by classic synthetic methodologies, not to mention that it represents an important way of introducing a reactive center into the poorly functionalized kaurenoic acid skeleton.

sec.title: 2.2. QSAR results
sec.p: The data set consisting of selected descriptors (log P , εHOMO and εHOMO- 1 in Supplementary information, Table S1 ) was split into training (20 compounds) and test (5 compounds) sets, after removing compound 7 . This compound is structurally different, as a large and different group to all other substituents was introduced at C-15 position.

The dendrogram from hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA; Fig. 2a ) was obtained for all kaurenoic acid derivatives. The Ward's method, as highlighted by
, was applied to construct the dendrogram. The selected compounds for the test set ( 10 , 15 , 23 , 24 , and 25 ) are highlighted, showing that all groups were well represented, considering the structural variability and IC50 range. Compounds 23 and 24 are the most active in the test set (IC50 = 66.47 and 68.01 μmol L −1, respectively), while compounds 25 and 10 are moderately active (94.32 and 151.60 μmol L −1) and compound 15 presents low activity (288.00 μmol L −1). It is possible to observe from Fig. 1 that among all tested compounds four of them ( 15 , 23 , 24 , and 25 ) are substituted at C-19 by different amide groups, whereas compound 10 presents a carboxyl group at this position. Compounds 23 , 24 and 25 present a double bond between C-16 and C-17, while a methoxy and hydroxyl groups were inserted at C- 16 in compounds 10 and 15 , respectively. The synthesized compound ( 27 ), of unknown biological activity, was included in this analysis in order to investigate its similarity to the other compounds in this series. Note that this compound was grouped with compound 21 .

The hierarchical cluster analysis performed for the training set ( Fig. 2b ) shows two groups, A and B. Group B is composed by the most active derivatives presenting, in most cases, IC50 values lower than 100.00 μmol L −1, except for compounds 1 , 9 and 26 (IC50 = 145.40, 257.00 and 136.00 μmol L −1, respectively). Group A is mainly composed by the least active ( 3 , 4 , 5 , 16 , 17 and 18 ) compounds, for which IC50 values are higher than 390.00 μmol L −1, and by the moderate activity derivatives 2 , 6 , 8 , 13 and 14 presenting IC50 values ranging from 141.00 to 251.90 μmol L −1. Group A is further divided into two subgroups, A1 and A2, being the least active derivatives present in A2, while A1 is constituted by compounds with moderate ( 2 , 6 , 13 and 14 ) and low ( 3 and 16 ) activity. These two subgroups can be classified as presenting moderate (A1) or low (A2) activity, while group B can be classified as the most active. It can be inferred from these results that the selected descriptors are able to distinguish the compounds into three classes: high, low or moderate activity.

The best PLS regression model for the training set was obtained with a factor describing a total variance of 69.92% and 3 descriptors (Supplementary information, Table S1 ) according to Eq. (1), where log P is the partition coefficient octanol/water, and εHOMO and εHOMO-1 are the energies of the highest and second highest occupied molecular orbitals:
where,

Leave- N -out cross validation (LNO) and y-randomization were performed in order to validate the model. The results in Fig. 3 show that the randomized models are of poor quality, as expected. The intercepts were 0.0396 ( Fig. 3A ) and −0.4631 ( Fig. 3B ), and are below the acceptable values of αR <0.3 and αQ <0.05 proposed by Wold and Ericksson and coworkers (
; Wold et al., 1984). The correlation between p IC50 and p IC50randomized is below 0.4, showing no chance correlation ( Fig. 3A and B ). Furthermore, Q2 and R2 for randomized y ( Fig. 3C ) are below 0.30, also indicating no chance correlation.

The results for leave- N -out cross validation ( Fig. 3D ) show that even after removing five compounds from the training set (20%), the Q 2 value remains close to Q 2 for Leave-one-out, with standard deviation not exceeding the limit of ± 0.05, indicating that the QSAR model is robust.
a p IC means –logIC (IC in mol L −1). 50 50 50 b Synthesized compound.
a Average relative error of prediction. b coefficient of determination for external validation. c Standard error of prediction.

From the best PLS model built on the auto-scaled data (Eq. (1)), –log IC50 increases with the increasing descriptor values, once they are all positive. The regression coefficients in equation (1) are similar, indicating that the descriptors are almost equally important in describing the model; however, the coefficient for log P is slightly higher than the others.

The HOMO and HOMO- 1 molecular orbital surfaces are graphically represented in Table 3 for the three most active compounds, the three least active and for compound 27 (synthesized compound). The molecular orbital surfaces were built from the distribution of electronic density on the molecule and their visualization helps understand which atomic orbitals are contributing to the formation of the molecular orbitals.

It can be observed from the most active compounds of the training set (derivatives 19 , 20 and 21 ) that the HOMO molecular orbitals are mainly located in the portion of the molecule containing the R1 substituent, while for compounds 4 and 5 , which show low activity, the HOMO surface is distributed over other molecular regions. This indicates that substituent R1 is participating in the interactions with the receptor. The HOMO of molecule 18 , the least active, also presents its HOMO surface on the R1 region, but log P for this molecule is quite low if compared to that of the most active compounds; furthermore, the energies of HOMO and HOMO–1 for compound 18 are also lower than that of most active compounds (Supplementary information, Table S1 ).

The increasing activity with log P , εHOMO and εHOMO-1 values suggests that more active compounds could be designed by modifying the radical R 1 in order to obtain more lipophilic substituents, which at the same time provide increased HOMO and HOMO- 1 energy values. Based upon these findings, two compounds ( 28 and 29 ) were proposed in this work ( Fig. 4 , B and
C
). The most active compound ( 19 , Fig. 1 ) was modified at R1 position in order to provide a more lipophilic derivative and in this way, the methoxy group (eOCH3) was substituted by a methyl group (eCH3) to generate compound 28 and afterwards by an ethyl group (eCH2eCH3) to result in compound 29 . The calculated log P values for both compounds were higher than for compound 19 , but HOMO and HOMO–1 energies were somewhat lower. The predicted p IC50 for these compounds were close to the p IC50 of the third most active compound, 21 ( Table 4 ). These results indicate that although log P values were higher than that of the most active compound, the predicted activities were close to the compounds with similar HOMO and HOMO- 1 energies. Another kaurenoic derivative was proposed, synthesized and tested in this work (compound
27 in
Table 4 ). This compound was also modified in the R1 position, but with a completely different substituent from that of the most active compound, 19 . Although this modification led to a logP value decrease, the HOMO energy of compound 27 is closer to that of active compounds 19 and 20 when compared to those of compounds 28 and 29 ( Table 4 ). All descriptor values for compound 27 were similar to the values of compound 21 and consequently, the estimated p IC50 (4.49 mol L −1) was slightly higher than that of compound 21 ( p IC50 = 4.37 mol L −1). This compound was tested a posteriori against MCF-7 breast cells and the experimental value for IC50 was 30.35 μmol L −1 ( p IC50 = 4.52 mol L −1), confirming the activity predicted by the model ( p IC50 observed – p IC50 predicted = 0.03).
50 ( p IC50pred
in mol L −1).

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p: A QSAR analysis for a set of 26 kaurenoic acid derivatives was tested in this study against breast cancer cells through PLS regression analysis. The model was validated by y-randomization and leave- N -out tests, in addition to external validation with a test set. Validation tests showed that the model is robust and presents a good prediction power. According to the PLS regression equation, the activity against MCF-7 breast cancer cells is related to log P and HOMO and HOMO–1 energies, such that the higher log P , HOMO and HOMO- 1 energies, the higher the activity. The positive relationship between these orbitals and the activity indicates that interaction with the target occurs mainly by charge displacement from the kaurenoic acid derivatives to the cell target. This finding corroborates with the literature in the sense that the drug-receptor interactions for this class of compounds with carcinogenic activity are predominantly guided by charge transfer or charge displacement. In addition, the graphical representations of the HOMO and HOMO- 1 molecular orbital for active compounds suggest that charge displacement occurs mainly from substituent R1. The activity increase in log P , εHOMO and εHOMO-1 values indicates that more active compounds could be designed by modifying the radical R1 with more lipophilic substituents, which at the same time give the molecules higher HOMO and HOMO- 1 values. Based on these results, three compounds were proposed and one of them was synthesized and tested. The experimental result confirmed the activity predicted by the model.

sec.title: 4.1. General procedures
sec.p: NMR spectra were recorded either on a Bruker Avance DRX 400 or on a Jeol 300 MHz spectrometer. Samples were dissolved in CDCl3, pyridine-d or MeOD, and TMS was used as internal reference. The biotransformation procedures were performed on a Cientec CT-713 rotary shaker. All solvents were anhydrous and the reactions to obtain compound 27 were performed under an inert atmosphere unless aqueous. All round-bottom flasks were kept dried in an oven under 100 ° C .

sec.title: 4.2. Kaurenoic acid isolation
sec.p:
Kaurenoic acid was isolated from 150.0 g
Copaifera
ssp oleoresin which was chromatographed through several chromatographic methods, as previously reported by Simão and coworkers (Simao et al., 2016). The identification of such compound was performed by spectroscopic analysis and compared with literature data (
).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 4.3. Microbial transformation of kaurenoic acid by Aspergillus terreus

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Prof. Dr. Suraia Said from the Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences of Ribeirão Preto, University of São Paulo , Brazil provided the
Aspergillus terreus
strain used in the biotransformation processes. This microorganism was maintained as a conidial suspension preparation on silica gel (6–12 mesh, grade 40, desiccant-activated), at 4 °C. The microbial transformation experiments were conducted using submerged shaken liquid culture and two-stage fermentation procedures. An inoculum of 1.73 × 10 7 conidia/mL was aseptically added to ten Erlenmeyer flasks (1000 mL) containing 500 mL of seed medium, as previously described in the literature (
). Cultures were incubated at 30 °C using a shaker operating at 120 rpm. After 24 h of incubation, the resulting mycelia were harvested, rinsed, and aseptically transferred to ten Erlenmeyer flasks (2000 mL) containing 1000 mL of sterile medium consisting of sucrose (3.0%), NaNO3 (0.2%), K2HPO4 (0.05%), MgSO4.7H2O (0.05%), KCl (0.05%), and FeSO4.7H2O (0.001%). After 24 h, 40 mL of 25.0 mg mL −1 of kaurenoic acid in dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) were equally distributed among the seven flasks, which were incubated again. Incubation was stopped after fourteen days and the cultures were filtered. The resulting aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate (20 × 1000 mL) to yield the extract labeled AtE (
A. terreus
extract; 2.24 g ) after solvent evaporation. Culture (culture medium containing microorganisms only incubated with DMSO) and substrate (sterile medium containing the same amount of kaurenoic acid incubated under the experimental condition) controls were also prepared for this strain
.

sec.title: 4.4. Isolation of diterpenes obtained by microbial transformation
4.5. Synthesis of compound 27
sec.p: The synthesis of compound 27 was performed according to published procedures (Simao et al., 2016). The crude product was purified by automated flash chromatography eluting with hexanes/ethyl acetate.

sec.title: 4.6. Cell viability assay - XTT
sec.p: The human breast carcinoma cell line (MCF-7 cells) was obtained from the Cell Bank of Rio de Janeiro (BCRJ code 0069) and cultured. Diterpenes were dissolved in a 0.1% DMSO solution (stock concentration of 0.1 M) and a serial dilution was performed to obtain concentrations ranging from 1000.0 to 0.975 μg mL −1. To determine the viability, cells were seeded in complete medium (1 × 10 4 cells/well) in 96 well plates and 24 h after treatment, plates were washed twice with phosphate buffer saline and incubated 4 h at 37 ° C with DMEM without phenol red but containing XTT dye, as recommended by the manufacturer. Statistical analysis of experimental data was performed using the GraphPad InStat 3.0 software and IC50 values were calculated. Doxorubicin and DMSO 0.1% were employed as positive and solvent controls, respectively. Details to this procedure were previously described (Simao et al., 2016).

sec.title: 4.7. Computational methods
4.8. Multivariate data analysis (PLS) and QSAR studies
sec.p: An a priori regression model was built to perform variable selection and investigate the presence of outliers. This model also allowed determining the number of latent variables in the model. The construction of the final model and external validation was carried out after splitting the total set of 26 compounds into training and test sets. Hierarchical cluster analysis built with the R software version 3.2.1 (2015) shows that all groups were well represented in the selected test set, considering the structural variability and IC50 range. The predictive power of the PLS model was determined by the coefficient of multiple determination of prediction ( R2 pred ) and standard error of prediction (SEP).

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: The authors are thankful to FAPESP (Processes number: 2007/ 54762-8, 2011/23028-2, 2011/07623-8 and 2011/13630-7), CAPES and CNPq for funds and grants.

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2018.10.005.
